The UN represents the countries of the world. And the countries of the world represent the population of those countries. So ultimately, the way the UN treats countries is similar to how people treat the people who live in those countries.

That's why the UN couldn't care less about millions dying in Africa, be it in massive wars that kill millions, or actual genocides and mass starvation, that's happening right now. That's why they mostly don't mind when Arabs are killing other Arabs, unless they can somehow tie the Jews to it (compare Yemen and Gaza, Damour and Sabra and Shatila, and so on). 

And yes, how they treat the Jewish state, is largely a reflection of how the world sees the Jews. With a strong portion (many of whom led by actual, Holocaust-denying antisemites, from countries where 80%-90% of the population have classically antisemitic views) arguing that the Jews are not just the worst evil in the world, but worse than all the other evils combined. And everyone else agreeing that even if that's not true, the Jews' existence, and ability to defend themselves, is not given, as with other countries, but conditional on the goodwill of their non-Jewish rulers.

With that said, I don't think just saying "the UN is antisemitic" will convince anyone. Not even pointing out that one of the people who wrote this report, literally said that the "Jewish lobby" is controlling social media. A statement mirrored by the UNHRC's other vehicle for anti-Israeli propaganda reports, internationally-recognized antisemite Francesca Albanese, when she said that the US is controlled by the Jewish lobby. Some people, ultimately, will never agree that anything can be antisemitic, including literal mass murder of Jews. Even view the label "antisemitic" as a badge of honor - a behavior that was used to be limited to Neo-Nazis, but now has spread to people who identify as non-racists. But it's much harder to argue that the UN is a "Western based organization", and there's anything notable about it lambasting the "Western allied state" of Israel. That's not some subjective judgement call, that can be dismissed by saying the Jews are lying about being targets of racism. It's just obviously, objectively, untrue.

>Under Netanyahu they've long resisted meaningful Palestinian statehood

**Why**? Is there a reason why they would not want a Palestinian State?

Only [16% of Jewish Israelis](https://www.pewresearch.org/global/2025/06/03/israeli-public-is-increasingly-skeptical-about-lasting-peace/) think that lasting peace is possible with a potential Palestinian State. Only [28% of the population feels safe](https://www.inss.org.il/publication/survey-june-2025/). 

[Half of Israelis](https://www.pewresearch.org/global/2025/06/03/views-of-the-potential-for-lasting-peace/) do not think that a two-state solution is possible.

>They openly call for annexing the West Bank and have dismissed Palestinian national identity as 'an invention.'

How much power do they actually hold?

>Ben-Gvir himself is a disciple of hardline Kahanist ideology and is currently in charge of the the National Security Ministry, he‚Äôs advocated (and facilitated) arming settlers, encouraged police crackdowns on Arab citizens, and even suggested stripping disloyal Arab Israelis of citizenship.

Again, how much **political** power does he wield? Does he have the political means to achieve these ideals?

Gvir has a [54% unfavorable](https://www.pewresearch.org/global/2025/06/03/views-of-israeli-and-palestinian-political-leaders/) rating.

>While they are less openly militant, they do support coalition policies that entrench permanent control over the territories while extracting concessions on religion-state issues that erode secular Israeli's rights.

Once again, do they wield political power to achieve these goals?

>they pushed judicial reforms aimed at weakening checks and balances inside Israel itself.

>pushed for weakening Israel‚Äôs High Court, the same court that in theory provides some protection for minority rights.

**This** is what people should be protesting against. The problem is that Netanyahu and other right wing politicians keep getting elected because of the increase of terrorism that happened under left leaning governments. Only [1% of Israelis want Hamas](https://www.pewresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/20/2025/05/SR_25.05.09_gaza_1.png?resize=420,386) to stay in power after the war. Netanyahu is still [polling almost 3x higher](https://www.jns.org/poll-60-of-israelis-back-return-to-fighting-in-gaza/) than his potential opponent.

Terrorism has to get under control if Israel has any hope of addressing the threats that the right wing politicians pose to the governmental structure.

[There is dedicated Wiki page](https://he.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D7%94%D7%92%D7%99%D7%A8%D7%AA_%D7%A4%D7%9C%D7%A1%D7%98%D7%99%D7%A0%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%9E%D7%A8%D7%A6%D7%95%D7%A2%D7%AA_%D7%A2%D7%96%D7%94) on the subject (alas, Hebrew only), here is lightly edited Google translate of relevant section:

>During the Gaza War, Egypt closed the border with Gaza, preventing Palestinians from leaving the Gaza Strip. Despite this, hundreds of Gazans left through the crossing every day.
>
>Until the closure of the Rafah crossing on May 6, 2024, approximately 5,000 Gazans, sick and accompanied, had left for medical treatment in other countries. Since then, until early July 2024, several dozen people had left for medical treatment through the Kerem Shalom crossing. On July 1, 2024, the government committed to the Supreme Court to establish a mechanism that would allow Gazans to leave for medical treatment outside of Israel. On July 30, 2024, 148 patients and their companions left for medical treatment in the United Arab Emirates. On August 15, 2024, 26 Gazans were reported to have left for medical treatment in Jordan. In early November 2024, 231 Gazans were flown to the United Arab Emirates and Romania for medical treatment.

I think this  article was very insightful. Please read it: [https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c1dgqn7nq0no](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c1dgqn7nq0no) and please note that the BBC is frequently criticized for their anti-Israel news coverage and breached their own editorial standards to do so [https://variety.com/2024/tv/global/bbcs-israel-hamas-coverage-breached-editorial-guidelines-asserson-report-1236137850/](https://variety.com/2024/tv/global/bbcs-israel-hamas-coverage-breached-editorial-guidelines-asserson-report-1236137850/)

  
When you read the BBC article, did you notice how they mentioned affluent neighborhoods in Gaza?

The narrative has long been that Gaza was a concentration camp. An open air prison. Yet they have affluent neighborhoods. Concentration camps did not have luxury accommodations for the wealthy. Neither do prisons. 

So I think the destruction of Gaza should be reported through the stories of Gazans who lived through the destruction. Let them report what they lost. 

I feel this for two reasons:

1) Reports from Gazan citizens will give a clearer picture of how their lives changed since the war, which will yield a much more accurate account of what Gaza was like before the war. Let Gazans report on how their 10 room apartment was destroyed. How they no longer have access to swimming pools and tennis courts. Because they did lose these things. However, concentration camps and prisons typically don't offer spacious living arrangements and swimming lessons. Let the lie of Gaza being a concentration camp or a prison die.

2) There are affluent neighborhoods in Gaza largely because Hamas compensates itself handsomely from funds that are supposed to provide for the people of Gaza. Let the Hamas members and their associates identify themselves to the world.

The sense of self importance among my fellow Jews is astounding. His victory isn‚Äôt about Israel. He tries to barely even talk about Israel. He‚Äôs the mayor of NEW YORK CITY.

I get it, it‚Äôs a city with the biggest population of Jews outside of Israel so it‚Äôs a special place to us. My family immigrated to New York. All my Jewish half of the family is from New York.

But we CANNOT base our important domestic decisions on a complicated moral issue happening elsewhere. It‚Äôs not even that complicated. Don‚Äôt hold it against someone for being against violence and then also call him a terrorist. He doesn‚Äôt have to have fully formed opinions about Israel.

NYC is for all immigrants not just the Jewish ones. My Irish immigrant side also came to New York. What I keep telling my mom is, the lessons we‚Äôre supposed to learn from our people‚Äôs history isn‚Äôt that Jews are special. It‚Äôs that you have to treat everyone humanely. Every immigrant! Gay! Disabled! People of every ethnicity. People from anywhere. 

In the absence of being someone who makes decisions for Israel, he doesn‚Äôt need to explain why he has previously expressed that RELIGIOUS NATIONALISM IS BAD! Aren‚Äôt you all seeing it here? The evangelical Christians are the problem. We actually share in being a religious minority (in America) with Muslims and it‚Äôs something it seems younger people cherish and the more traditional older Jewish people I know usually fail entirely to see.

Edit to clarify my last paragraph: the evangelical Christian‚Äôs brand of nationalism is the problem in the USA at this time.
